newsitem.title: UK: China 96/97 sugar imports seen at 2 mln T - analyst.
newsitem.headline: China 96/97 sugar imports seen at 2 mln T - analyst.

text.p: China is likely to import some two million tonnes of sugar in the 1996/97 crop year to reflect the increasing rate of local consumption, an F.O. Licht analyst said on Thursday.

"Despite the ban on imports, shipments amounted to almost two million tonnes in 1995/96 and given the modest growth in per capita consumption, a similar tonnage can be expected for 1996/97," Licht's Christoph Berg told a two-day conference hosted by Agra Europe.
"China can be defined as a structural deficit region with the size of imports depending on domestic production for its tremendous demand potential," he said.
High domestic prices and liberal import rules sparked a wave of illegal imports estimated at some 1.5 million tonnes despite a brief excursion on to the export markets in 1995, he added.
After this, the government re-took control and banned sugar imports under general trade items in 1996.
But the state policy on sugar imports was likely to be subject to political pressures as China prepared to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), Berg said.

"As the move to ban sugar imports is likely to hurt the country's prospects of joining the WTO, the most effective instruments of the Chinese trade policy are unlikely to remain at the politicians' disposal for an unlimited time."
At the start of the 1990s China changed from being a substantial net sugar importer into an exporter and then back to importer within a very short period, he said.
